editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE MOCK-DUELLIST, OR, The French Vallet. A COMEDY.
Acted at the THEATRE ROYAL, By his Majeſties Servants.
LONDON: Printed by J. C. for William Crooke, at the Green Dragon without Temple-bar. 1675.

div.head: TO THE VERTUOUS ACCOMPLISHED Lady, MADAM S. C.
div.p: THe French Vallet, according to his natural Inſolence, throws himſelf at your feet; not in his broken Engliſh, with a Begar Madam, mee voul ave it de ſo, but in that Dialect uſed by the moſt refin'd Wits, —Vous ſupplye tres humblement Le regarder d'un aſpect favorable.

Which bleſsing he vows is a ſufficient ſaveguard againſt thoſe three Fatalities of Books; Envy, Spight, and Malice. I know, Madam, that to have ſhrowded under your generous protection all that the greateſt Gallantry of the two moſt Polite Nations of the world could have wound up to the higheſt ſublimity of Wit, had worn ſome face of Juſtice, which might have rendred the preſumption excuſable; it being ſo generally known, that none with more reaſon
than your ſelf, could undertake the Cenſure of what is ſo much your own; I mean La parfaite cognoiſſance du beau Monde. But Champagne's Crime can plead no excuſe; and being beyond the reach of
• rdinary Clemencie, can have no other hopes, than in
• hat goodneſs which ſhines with ſo much Luſtre
• hroughout all your actions. Take pitty of him, Madam; and while your hand is in, pardon alſo the
• iberty which his Advocate takes, of ſubſcribing himſelf,

closer.signed: Your moſt humble Servant, P. B.

div.head: THE PROLOGUE.
div.l: YE who will judge, and ye that can indeed,
(And Right, rather than long Preſcription plead,)
To both we equally do bow this night,
Owning the Power of one and th'other's right.
Our Poet ſays, h'as brought you a new Play,
Or if no new diſh—dreſs'd another way,
And better too, he thinks—Plot, Humour, Wit,
(The Devil's in it if it do not hit)
Leading you not through horrid rugged ways;
Knows better how to pleaſe, than to amaze.
Of Lines of Wonder you have had enow,
That poſe your Intellect, and th' Authors too;
And to this Ages ſpight will live perplex't,
To dare the Ʋnderstanding of the next.
His eaſier Scene no big-ſwoln rumbling ſpeaks,
That while you look on't, like a Bubble breaks,
Tumbling along with an amazing noiſe;
But his accoaſt is gentle Nature's voice.
In this conceit he brisks, begins to ſwell,
And ſwears he ſhall come off at leaſt as well
As ſome applauded Freemen of the Trade,
Whom neither Art nor Nature Poets made.
'Twere brave if 't would go thus, and you ſhould be
Perſwaded to believe't as well as he.
But he'll go leſs; for all this little Huff,
At other intervals he's tame enough,
And wiſely then conſiders what is due▪
From his bold weakneſs, to ſuch Powers as you;
You whoſe Prerogative is underſtood
To give the ſtamp, and make the Mettle good,
With Priviledge as great and unconfin'd
As his, who Leather into Money coin'd.

list.head: A CATALOGUE of BOOKS Newly Printed for William Crook.
list.item: 1. SIr Henry Blunt's Voyage into the Levant, in 12. Price 1 s.
2. The Flower-garden, ſhewing how all ſorts of Flowers are to be Ordered. The time of Flowering, taking them up, and Planting them, &c. By W. Hughes, 12. Price 1 s.
3. Poems of the Right Reverend Dr. Rich. Corbet, late Lord Biſhop of Norwich. Corrected and inlarged. Price 1 s.

4. The American Phyſitian; ſhewing all the Vertues, Uſes, &c. of all the Roots, Plants, &c. in the Engliſh Plantations in America: With a Diſcourſe teaching how to make Chocolette, &c. By W. Hughes. Price 1 s.
5. The Court of Curioſity; being the moſt Witty Fortune-book and Learnedeſt Interpretations of Dreams, &c. ever extant. Tranſlated out of French, by J. G. Gent. Price 2 s.
6. Vittoria Corombona, or the white Devil. A Tragedy. Acted at the Theatre Royal. Written by J. W. Price 1 s.
7. The Old Troop, or Monſieur Raggou. A Comedy. Acted at the Theatre Royal. Price 1 s.
8. The Memoires and Adventures of Sylvia Moliere. Price 2 s.
9. Ʋlyſſes's Travels. By Mr. Hobbes. In Engliſh Verſe. Price 1 s.
10. Calliope's Cabinet opened and reviewed; wherein all Gentlemen, of what Rank ſoever, may know how to Adorn themſelves for Feaſtings, &c. By J. Salter. Price 8 d.
11. A New Collection of Poems and Songs, wrote by the preſent Wits of the Age, upon ſeveral Subjects. Price 1 s. 6 d.
12. A Diſcourſe of the Dukedom of Modena, being the preſent Dutcheſs of Yorks Country. Price 6 d.
13. Brevis Demonſtratio: A Diſcourſe proving Chriſtianity by Reaſon. Price 10 d.
14. Catalines Conſpiracie. A Tragedy. Acted a • the Theatre Royal. Wrote by Ben. Johnſon. Price 1 s.
15. The Primitive Inſtitution. By L. Addiſon, one of the Kings Chaplains. Price 1 s. 6 d.

list.head: BOOKS Printed this Year 1675. For William Crook.
list.item: 1. Homer's Odyſſes: Tranſlated into Engliſh, by Tho. Hobbes of Malmsbury; with a large Preface concerning the Vertues of an Heroique Poem. Price 4 s.

2. The Preſent State of the Jews (more particularly thoſe relating to Barbary) wherein is contained an exact Account of their Cuſtoms Secular and Religious: Diſcovered by the many years converſation with their R. R. By L. Addiſon, D. D. one of his Majeſties Chaplains in Ordinary. Price 2 s 6 d.

3. The Juriſdiction and Lawfulneſs of the Authority of Courts Leet, Baron, Marſhalſea, Pypowder, and Antient Demeſn, &c. by J. Kitchin: To which is now added a Collection of choice Writs, by R. A. and T. J. The Fifth Edition. Price 6 s.
4. The Third Volume of Mr. Tho. Hobbes his Works (containing what is omitted in the two Volumes printed at Amſterdam) in Quarto. Price 10 d.
5. The Golden Rule made plain and eaſie, by a ſhort Method, different from that which is commonly found in Books of Arithmetick. By C. H. Price 3 d.
6. De Mirabilibus Pecci, carmen Tho. Hobbes Malmſbury. Price 6 d.
7. Enterpe Revived; being Epigrams on the moſt Eminent Perſons of Honour now living. Price 1 s.
8. The Amorous Gallant: or Love in Faſhion. A Comedy, in Heroick Verſe, as it was Acted. Price 1 s.

body.head: THE Mock-Duelliſt, OR, The FRENCH VALLET.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: ONce more I tell thee, Boy, thou ſhalt have Gold:
Wilt thou not take my word? By theſe two Reliques.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: Prethee hold faſt; thou haſt but little hold.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Why, there's the thing, that's it whets my revenge;
The little fleſh I loſt on either ſide,
Through the ſeverity of old Sir Amorous
The Juſtice that lives in that Corner-houſe,
Has ſwollen my ſpleen to that exceſs of rage,
That nothing but the greateſt of Revenge
I can invent, is able to allay it.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: It was ſharp dealing, I muſt needs confeſs.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Moſt certain. Hear, what I've already done
In order to this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: Out with't, man.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I am of late poſſeſs'd with the affections
Of a young Lady at a Boarding-ſchool,
Who, notwithſtanding her ſevere reſtraint,
Has made a ſhift to give me her conſent
To Marry me.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: To Marry thee, ſay'ſt thou?
I'th' name of Fortune, for what doſt thou paſs?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: For nothing leſs than a Lords younger Brother,
What with my Tongue, my Perſon, and Gay Clothes:
My ſtories have ſo tickled her young heart,
She wiſhes hard this day be at an end,
That in the darkneſs o'th' ſucceeding night
I might (as I have promis'd) ſteal her hence.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: But what's all this to Sir Amorous Frost?
Let's hear what thy revenge prompts thee to do.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Why thus: in this ſervile ſort of diſguiſe
Thou ſeeſt, I have oftentime met our Juſtice;
As often pre-poſſeſt him with the love
Of my new Miſs unto his Worſhip's perſon;
Inſomuch, that what with Letters and Bills,
Together with ſome other circumſtances
Too long to tell, I have ſo fill'd his head
With fingle-fangles, that he is reſolv'd
This night (through her deſires, as he thinks)
To get her off, by a Ladder of ropes,
And then to marry her. Now comes the ſport:
Get you in readineſs, 'twixt two and three
This very night, half a dozen ſtout Lads
Fitly diſguis'd to act the Watch-mens parts;
Your rendezvous ſhall be at the ſtreet-end.
Fail not in this, and leave me to the reſt.
I had almoſt forgot to let thee know,
That French man whom I cunningly got off
The laſt Seſſions but two▪

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: An excellent Rogue!

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I have diſpos'd of to our Amorous Knight,
As a preſent from his Miſs.

div.l: Look, look, yonder he comes; ſtep you aſide:
We'll both in here, and mark what he will do.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Come, come, turn out I ſay.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Jerny mee voul
Et den your Madmoiſel turn de you out:
Begar mee go tell de her you no propre
To make de Gentleman; you no moſt have
De French Vallet, dat is geanty, galland,
No fit for de you dat: Jerny moſt have
De doll, de Diable, de ſimple Engliſh man
To ſerve de you, dat can no teſh de you
De Gallantry; no ſo moſh as de ſpake.
Fee, fee, begar, no me ſhame for de you
Jerny, mee voul go, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Should he in ſpite
Go tell my Miſtris this, it might ſpoil all,
When I conſider that ſhe put him to me,
By the means of her confident, that man
Who interchangeably conveys our Letters,
The ſole Correſpondencie we ever had,
Through her ſevere reſtraint: I muſt ſubmit.
Champagne, do but reflect on what y'have done.
Y'have ſtolen my Linnen, loſt your Hat and Clothes,
Spent all that Money I'd giv'n you to lay out,
Which was five or ſix pounds.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee lay it ote, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: On your own ſelf, and give me no accompt.
Home you come naked, hundred Boys at your heels;
Then fit your ſelf afreſh from my beſt ſtore,
All without Licence.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Begar, 'tis no de faſſon
De Franſhe ſerviteur de aſk de permiſſion;
Look de your Papier, and you voul ſee
It is de mee devoir to ſheet de you.
Begar, you no underſtand de Civilité
Francoiſe; you call de ſheet, dat is ſimplement
De gaillardiſe, de tour d'addreſſe, Jerny.
It is meſkin, begar.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I muſt be quiet,
And for the preſent wink at all his faults;
But time will come, I ſhall alter the Scene.
Well, well, Champagne, upon condition
That for the future you'll live orderly,
All ſhall be now forgot. I will allow you
A Crown a day, and you ſhall promiſe me
That you'll be honeſt, and cheat me no more.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Vell, toſh de la? do mee loſe bee de bargain,
Mee vould oblige de you. Come, give l'argent.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Well, well, let's in, and I'll give it thee there.

div.stage: As Sir Am. is going in, Shift ſteps to him, and gives him a Letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Another Letter?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Leſt the former ſhould fail,
In ſpeaking not clear enough her intentions.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: How does ſhe do? Does ſhe look briſkly on't?
Thou ſeeſt I do: ſpeak; Is ſhe chearful, man?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: As her Impatiencie, Sir, will permit.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Take this for thy reward.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I thank your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: 'Tis a very ſmall hand: where are my Spectacles?
Now let me ſee.

body.p: Since you have been ſo punctual to obſerve all my Injunctions, I can no more doubt of your real Affections; I ſhall think the time long till I am claſp'd within the loving Circle of your arms. This night if you will come to receive me as yours, 'twixt one and two, I ſhall impatiently expect your preſence at the ſecond window next the Garden, where you will finde

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Let me ſee that again?
Yours wholly, Kath. Noble? 'tis juſt ſo.
I muſt not doubt your ſecrecie in this?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I'll be as ſecret to you as your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: 'Tis very well; that Vertue is a Jewel
Which muſt be ſet in Gold. Here, take the reſt.
Only an earneſt of my future love.
Thou muſt aſſiſt me in this my deſigne,
In this Amorous Theft.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Sir, I am yours.
I'll not be wanting: be you but diſguis'd,
And I'll ſecure you all.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Truſt me for that
I can do it naturally, as it were.
What odd diſguiſe doſt thou think would do beſt?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: A woman's dreſs, nothing were better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Th'art in the right: but how ſhould I come by it
Without ſuſpition?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Leave that, Sir, to my care.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I prethee do, and be ſure not to fail
Preciſely at th'appointed time and place.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: I'd as ſoon diſappoint a Rich young wife,
As fail your Worſhip, Sir. This night at two
I ſhall be punctual, Sir—to plague your heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Champagne, come here.
How doſt thou like me now?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O! ver vell—
Begar you loke de no, Juſtement,
Comme de young Gallant: you have de odre day▪
De bougre de hair all vitt, et no you have
De Peruque friſee; you vant
No more, Jerny, que de feat, venſh et drink.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Fight, wench, and drink? I'm old-dog at that.
This Love is a ſtrange thing: I'm young again.
Henceforth to Juſtice I muſt bid adieu;;
That becomes not my Youth. Judge thou Champagne
Whether this Wig and Sute would fit the Bench.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: No par ma foy, es bettre too ſand tim
For de la Commedy▪

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: How do I walk?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O ho! mee toſh you dat.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: And ſing? fa-la-la-la-

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee teſh you dat.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: And fence? ha ha!

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee teſh you dat.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Oddſniggs▪ I had forgot
My French, Champagne.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Oh! mee no teſh▪ you dat.
Odnigg, odnigg, dat pitiful, Jerny,
Dat juſtement come de povre diable.
Alon donc? Qu'on prenne ſa lecon
Par la Mort, par la Teſte.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Par la Mort, par la Teſte.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Bon, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Bon Jerny.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Aye? no ſaye bon Jerny.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Aye? no ſay bon Jerny.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Diable ſoit de la beſte.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Diable ſoit de la beſte.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ah! Jerny, holl, holl: no ſay after me,
Je donne au diable Madamoiſelle.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Je donne, &c.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Si je ne ſuis le plus humble ſerviteur.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Si je ne ſuis, &c.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: De tous les ſerviteurs de vos Valets.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: De tous les ſerviteurs, &c.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Very goot! alon, encore!

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Very goot, alon, encore.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Non! Madamoiſelle je ſuis rany d'avoir donné
Juſques dans la Contre eſcarpe de vos bonnes graces.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Madamoiſelle, &c.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Fort bien? no for de dance, Alerte Jerny.
Stand de you very ſtrait, juſt come de mee.
So, very goot.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Now let me ſee whether I have obſerv'd
Exactly her Commands: this is her Note,
Written with her own hand. In the firſt place,
You are to be apparell'd i'th' French Mode,
To have this French Vallet, Companion rather,
Who is to teach you to Dance, Sing, and Fight,
To ſpeak a Norman, or a Gaſcon French;
To Swear and Curſe, in the ſame Dialect;
And cheat you of your Linnen, Clothes, and Caſh,
Before your face; at which you muſt but laugh.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Oh! O! do you ſee no? pray obſerve dat.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: And ſwear by Jove, it is a witty Knave.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Un Crown de day? mee looſe be de bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Then I muſt have you court ſome Gayſome Lady,
To accuſtom your ſelf 'gainſt you have me.
Jerny, Champagne, je had forgot this laſt.
Haſt vous incontinent to Monſieur Coggin,
Et know quand je can waite upon the Madmoiſell.
Madmoiſell Phill. Airy, pour kiſs her bais les mains.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha! mee go preſentement.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Champagne, did'ſt thou not laugh at me, juſt now?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ma foy un little.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: There's for thy pains. Be gone.
At thy return thou't finde me in the Hall.

div.head: SCENE II. A Street.
div.stage: Per. Phill. Phan. and Siſs at a diſtance.
Per. in a Riding habit; the Women in Morning-dreſſes, and Vizard-masks.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I Had intelligence a fortnight ſince
Of his coming to Town to wooe the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The Widdow Lovewealth, ſay'ſt?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: The very ſame
Which put me on the buſineſs you ſhall hear.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Out with't; I long to hear't.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Thus in ſhort.
You are to know my adverſion towards Crosby
Being grown up unto a hatred of him,
By the ſad narrative which Madam Phanny
Had made me of his baſe treachery towards her,
Caus'd on the other hand a ſuddain growth
To thoſe well-wiſhings I had for Sir Coggin
Into affections—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Otherwiſe call'd Love.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: It ſhall be what you pleaſe. This made me ſeek
All handſome means to break off thoſe concerns
Which my Knight had, with th'intereſt Lady Lovewealth.
I ſoon made with his Siſter a firm league,
And did ſo order things, 'tis now a week
That I lie in their Lodgings, where I have had
More opportunity to work my ends.
Laſt night I did contrive ſo, that a Letter
Was delivered into Sir Coggins's hands
In preſence of me, with this Meſſage to't▪
That it was ſent from an unknown Lady▪
In which was mention'd, that he ſhould meet this day
In the Piazza at four a clock a perſon
That likely would inform him of ſome things
Of his neareſt concerns. He read the Note,
And preſently aſſur'd the Meſſenger
He ſhould not fail the aſſignation.
I had juſt parted with him, when I met
Timothy Clay, with his Man and his Dog,
Inquiring earneſtly of each he met
Concerning me, who was but juſt gone by▪
When I met you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, but what ſaid Sir Cogging?
Did he not know thee, think'ſt?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Not in the leaſt.
I told him in a counterfeited voice,
The Lady Lovewealth did deſpiſe him ſo,
That a Rival was entertain'd by this
In his own room: if therefore he'd deſiſt
His purſuit in that place, a worthy Lady
Would entertain his Love, who ſurely had
Such an eſteem for's perſon, as would amount
To th' making him her Huſband.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I did not give him time, but added ſtrait,
That if he'd meet me in that place again
'Twixt five and ſix, I ſhould inform him further.
To which he anſwer'd, that he would not fail.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How durſt thou venter thy ſelf all-a-lone
Without company with thee? Where is Siſs?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Thoſe two perſons you ſee there—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Who be they? Doſt thou know them?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Yes, I do.
The one is Madam Phanny, th'other Siſs.
Thus all-along they've kept me company,
At ſuch a diſtance as you ſee they obſerve.
Here's Tim. Clay, Brother, we muſt not be known.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Let me alone for that: art ſure 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: My life on't, man. T'is beſt I ſhould retire,
And leave him to your handling: if he bite,
Bring him in the back-way, there I'll confirm
Whatever you have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Say no more, wench.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Do you know our Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Where ſhe lives?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Perhaps I might, did I but know her name.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Why her name is pritty Miſtriſs Phill. Airy.
What ſay you now?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That I do know the perſon;
And if you pleaſe, I ſhall conduct you to her.
I am her ſervant, Sir,

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Say'ſt thou me ſo, friend?
A-gad-a-mercie fecks; give him a groate,
Clunch; come, diſpatch, a ſhall have a gray groate.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Oye, oye, ſoft there, pray let him earn it firſt.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: But harke you now, what kinde of ſervant pray?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: My Profeſſion, Sir—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oye, oye, let's hear, what's that?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Is to inſtruct both Gentlemen and Ladies
I'th' art of Compliments; beſides, I ſhew
To ſuch ſtrangers as you, the Town and Court,
The Gallantry thereof, and the Intrigue—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Intrigue? what place is that?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By that I mean
Th'ingenious converſation 'twixt the Wits
Of either Sex, both in the Court and City.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: You ſay that you teach Compliments?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Why then I'll tell you friend, 'twixt you and I,
I'm come to town to court a certain Lady,
Who is already courted to my hands;
But that for faſhion-ſake (a murrain on't!)
I muſt beſtow ſome few upon her Chaps.
Therefore, if you can help me to a braſe
O'th' neweſt of them at reaſonable Rate,
I'll be your Chapman: I have money enough;
Have I not, Clunch?

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Why, who dares queſtion that?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I do not in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: You were not beſt.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: But ſo few Complements, I am afraid
Will ſcarce ſerve turn.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Then keep them to your ſelf,
For I could never yet learn how to write,
Scarce how to read; and do you think that I
Will burden my membry with Complements?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What if I teach you the new Mode of Courtſhip,
In which you'll need but one ſingle Complement,
And all the reſt is voluntary Wit?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I marry, now you ſay ſomething indeed;
But what d'you mean by voluntary Wit?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis high Hyperboles, Anglicè Nonſenſe.
No matter, Sir, how wide 'tis from the matter,
So you but keep your Countenance, go on,
And ſcarce take time to breathe.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Thoſe what you call—
Hyper-bullies, and Anglicè Nonſenſe,
I ſhall ne're learn without book, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, Sir, ſuppoſe I have a way for that?
What can you then object?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I am not, Sir,
For your objects, I'm for one Complement:
And if ſo, why then ſo. Fecks you and I
Will be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, in ſhort,
Becauſe we are ſtrangers to one another,
For further ſatisfaction, if you pleaſe
To let me wait on you to th' Lady Airy,
She will inform you of my Capacity
In my Profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Gad-a-mercie fecks;
A dad a ſpeaks, Clunch, like an honeſt man:
Come, we'll along.

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: I Hope your Ladyſhip will none of him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Of whom talk'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Mr. Timothy Clay.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Thou ſilly thing! is he not wonderous Rich?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, and that's all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis all indeed:
For in that word is comprehended all
That I aſpire at. Suppoſe he be
The ill-bred Chip of a rough-hewn block;
Impertinent, abſurd, given to drink,
And to all ſottiſhneſs; what's that to me?
I'll endeavour ſomewhat to poliſh him:
If I cannot ſucceed, he take that courſe,
And I will even take this—

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Which, Madam, pray?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll give my ſelf all the freedom I can
In modeſty injoy; take th'advantages
Of all his beaſtly extravagancies.
I'll inſinuate my ſelf i th' management
Of the Eſtate; lull him aſleep with eaſe;
Yield a full ſcope to all his appetites,
While I will work my ends, hoord up his Gold,
And ſpend on't at my liſt, on this, or that;
Eat, drink, wear what I pleaſe; as often change:
Go out, come in again, early or late,
Without controle; have ſervants for my turn:
All this, and all things elſe, as I think fit.
What more can I deſire? would he were come:
I long to ſee the man.

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Sir Coggin, Madam,
Th'obliging Knight, what muſt become of him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Faith, Prew, e'en as he pleaſes; here 'twon't
I'm for the Richeſt ſtill.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The Taylor, Madam
Has brought ſome Patterns for your Ladyſhip.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Per. Phill. Clay, Clunch and Tray.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: SIr, in a word, he is the only man
On all accompts of Gallantry, you could
Have pitch'd upon.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Avads I think a be?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: And for your ſake, I'll diſmiſs him my ſervice;
He ſhall be wholly yours.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Neighbour, good thanks.
You hear, Sir? henceforth y'are to be mine;
Our Neighbour ſays the word.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Why very well. Now, becauſe I'm in haſte,
I'd have you dogmentiſe me inſtantly.
Was not that a hard word?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Moſt excellent!

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, ſometimes I hit on um, do you ſee?
Come, give me ſome diſtructions.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Very well.
Now, Sir, obſerve, ſince I'm fully inform'd
You do not care for troubling of your ſelf
With Compliments, I'll teach you the new Mode
A la Soldate.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Hy-day! what's that, I pray?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That is to ſay, Soldierlike Courtſhip, Sir;
A kinde of rough-hewn way newly come up,
Which takes wonderous well in Court and City:
'Tis generally us'd.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I long to know't.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why thus in ſhort: ſuppoſe that Lady there
Were your Maitreſs

div.stage: Per. comes up to Phill. in an affected way. Clay imitates redicul.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: That's Latin for my Lady?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No, Sir, 'tis French: thus I make my approach.
'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay fecks let me alone
To ſpeak all the dumb Courtſhip, do you ſee?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Thus having kiſs'd her hand, you muſt begin
Your Compliment.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Can't I do't without ſpeaking?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Not without ſpeaking, Sir: but do you mark,
That you may have no uſe of memory,
I'll write you down a Compliment.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, nay,
That will not do: for to tell you the truth,
I could never yet read a written hand,
Except it were in print.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo.
This done, and handſomely convey'd within your hat,
Which holding thus you ſhall read to you Lady,
She knowing not but you deliver it

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: That's French again; oye oye.
Efecks it will be brave.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Your Compliment
Delivered as is ſaid, you muſt begin
Either to whiſtle, ſing, hop up and down—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Or elſe play with my dog. But tell me though,
Suppoſe my Lady ſpeaks ſome Complements
To me again, what then?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why, if ſhe do,
She will not greatly minde what you will ſay,
Neither muſt you minde her.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: 'Tis very true.
For why ſhould I minde her, and ſhe not me?
Let me alone for that. That is, you ſay—
A la—what do you call it?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A la Soldat.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I'll defie any ſingle man in town
To do't better than I. Me thinks I'm at it.
Hie Tray! alas poor rogue!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: That's very well.
It is done to the life. After a while,
If you do find the Lady to be ſilent—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: So let her be! ſo I would have her fecks.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: You muſt begin—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: No Complements, I hope?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, then it will do well enough.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Only make uſe of ſome familiar talk:
As for example, What is moſt in faſhion,
What News abroad, or elſe of ſome new Play.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Or of my dog Tray; or elſe, do you ſee,
Tell her how many Beaſts, Sheep, Hogs; and Geeſe
My Father left me, beſides, Money and Lands
In ready Caſh.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: There's nothing better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: But yet, ſuppoſe ſhe has an itching minde
To Complement?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Then you muſt let her know
That being of opinion that Complements
Are of too ſoft a nature for a man
(Eſpecially of mettal) for to uſe,
Y'have hired me to ſupply in that part.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Effecks it will be rare.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Then will I court—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: The Lady, as for me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis very right.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oddſniggs, I had forgot where w'are to go.

div.l: Where ſhall I meet you 'bout an hour hence?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir, where you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Let it be in yond place—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The Piazza, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oye there an hour hence.
Neighbour Airy go to: y'have won my heart,
With leaving me your man.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your ſervant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, nay, no Complements; and ſo farewel.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Brother, what think you on't?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nothing but good.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: In my opinion, if I ben't miſtaken,
Here is a fortune flung into your arms:
You can't avoid it man, it muſt be ſo;
You are the man deſign'd to have the Lady
When all is done.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I hope no leſs, e'faith,
As I ſhall carry it on: for I intend,
As you may well perceive by this beginning,
That under the pretence of good inſtructions,
I'll make this credulous ſhallow-pated fool
Appear to be ſuch an impertinent Sot,
As will oblige the widdow without doubt
To ſee her folly in't if ſhe once moves.
Then will I take fair opportunity
By the fore-top, and ſpeak to her for my ſelf.
That, Girl, muſt be the way.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: A good one too.
Where's our brother Dick? would he were here:
Have you not heard of him?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By the laſt Poſt.
This is the day he is to be in town.
The fatal paſs, which ſo infortunately
He was compell'd to make in's own defence
Upon his enemy, is no more thought on:
For underhand he has of late compos'd,
And (though with great expence) is gotten clear.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I fear of's money as well as his troubles.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: It can't be helpt.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: He deſerves better things.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: His Ingenuity will never let him want.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I hope 'twill not.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Madam, Mr. Crosby
Demands admittance to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Why let him come; I ſhall ſoon diſpatch him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Mean time I'll go about the Compliment
Of ſuch a nature—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Into my Cloſet there.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Madam, I come to eaſe my poor ſick heart.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: If you are ſerious, you'll be beſt alone.
I have, Sir, other buſineſs now in hand.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Let me beg you'll be pleas'd but to conſider,
You can have none that may with greater Juſtice
Be taken to your thoughts, than ſuch a paſſion
As I have always manifeſted to you,
By the ſaddeſt proteſts—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Thoſe you call ſuch
I muſt ſuppoſe are of your making ſo,
Perhaps it is your cuſtom: I not the firſt
To whom y'have made thoſe ſad proteſts you call.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Let me but only vent—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: At leiſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: There's ſomething more than ordinary in the wind.
Should ſhe have had intelligence of late
Of my former Amours with Madam Phanny?
But how ſhould ſhe come by't? I need not fear't.
I muſt confeſs ſhe ever did receive
All my addreſſes with reluctancie;
Would often twit me with her friends conſent
Which I had got: but now of later daies
Sh'as not ſo much as common complaiſance.
Well, I'm reſolv'd once more to ſee this Miſs,
And pump out, if I can, the cauſe of this.

div.head: ACT. II. SCENE I. Sir Coggin's houſe.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: DEre is de hooſe, mee moſt knoke de dor:

div.l: Begar is be un very pritty de ting.
Mee voul make de her un grand Compliment.
Madamoiſelle, je ſuis voſtre eſclave d'un grand coeur.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Bleſs us! what have we here?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Vat have you de heer? Jerny, you have de Geante,
Jolly, polly, accomply, galland Gentilhome, Monſieur
De Briſefer; une perſone dat vill teſh de you de
Playe de Trumpet marine, de Flageolet, de
Feedle, de Tambour, de Baſque, de Signe, come ca
Fa-la-la-la, de Compliments, de Dance, come ca ha—
De Fence, come ſa, a, ha!—A Jerny mee voul feet,
A kill all de Diables for de love de you.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Sure this ſame thing has ſkipt out of its wits
Into this Morris-dreſs before the ſeaſon?
Hear you, pray, is not your name Champagne,
Sir Amorous Frost his ſervant?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ha, a, a, Champagne?
Me Modre bring de mee in de Champagne, et—

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Upon her back?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: No, begar, no ope de her belee—
Aye, ſo mee come in de varl in Champagne.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: You were born there?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Very juſt, par ma foy, mee born, mee born der.
But mee name bee Monſieur de Briſefer admirateur
De vos perfections.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Goodnow, no more conjuring.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: For de love de you mee voul brake de neck preſentement
Si'l vous plaiſt.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Good Sir, I thank you for your hanging love.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: A ha! voſtre tres humble Valet.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Well, but Champagne?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Aye!—

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Or Monſieur Briſefer, what is your Arrand?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Harrang, begar, Jerny, mee have no de Harrang, look
Der els;
sp.stage: (Shews his pockets, opens his breaſt and breeches.
sp.l: Mee come to baiſe les mains de Madmoiſelle
Diana, pour de ſervice de mee Maiſtre.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: What ſtuff is this? you baiſe les mains, Sot?
You kiſs her—

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Tout beau, tout beau, ma Genty de moiſelle, ventre,
Teſte, Gozoon, if de Rogue de Engliſhman ſpeak de
Mee de Harrang, me kill de him come ca, ha!
Ho! com come Madamoiſelle, ſur mon honneur
Mee voul no kill de you, harrang,
Jerny—

div.stage: Makes a Paſs at Lyſſe; ſhe runs, ſhreeks, he holds her back.
div.l: You ſay mee ſell de Harrang?

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Arrand, yes, Sir, I'm going of one,
And ſhould be glad you would inform me in't:
Pray where lives one whoſe name's Sir Hopewell Coggin?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Coquin? par la ſang, par la mort, par la teſte, Gozoon,
Harrang? Coquin? if no reſpect de Madmoiſelle
Mee voul—hum? Jerny—behange—

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: This is excellent ſport!

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Jerny, your ſelf:ſure this fellow is mad.
What do you ſay to me, pritty one? ha?
Can you inform me?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Jerny, he live in de houſe.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Pray leave off your Jerny: it may be ſo.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Sot? Madamoiſelle pray you hold de mee faſt,
Autrement mee kill de him preſentement.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: In what place is this houſe?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: In London, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Jerny in your teeth:
I'm a meer ſtanger, and—

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Et mee be un perſone voul make de you mad.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: where might I ſee him?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ver you look o-top de him, Jerny?

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Again? y'are pleaſant, Sir?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Begar me var mor plaiſant if you go to de divle
Si Joſois, Jerny—

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Fleſh and bloud can't hold out;
H'as gin me the Jerny a dozen times.
Pray change me this?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Peſte?—is it de jeſt ou bien de tout de bon?

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: E'en as you pleaſe; what do you think on't, pray?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: De jeſt, de jeſt, your humble ſerviteur.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Much good may do you, Sir: I'll go with you.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: La peſte? come il touche?—
Ha teſte non? ou eſt I'honneur? Champagne, ou eſt I'honneur?
Begar, mee voul have de revange; firſt mee vill kill
De Rogue, and den mee cogel im ſounlgle. Hah! Rogue,
Toſh mee de face? Premierement, call de mee de harrang,
Teſte non? en ſecond lieu, call de mee de Coquin? Par
La mort? Item, call de mee Sot? ha! ventre blew?
Concluſion, zap, give en grand box de Ear? ha! Jerny?
Es Juſtment come ca? dat is de ting. Mon honneur?
Verbee you? allon viſte ſpeak de me.
Mee ſay moſt have de reſpect for de Eſtranger—
Autrement mee kill de him, van, too, tree tim. O! forbon,
Very goot, you ſee no, mee honneur ave de reſpect et
De conſideration for de Eſtranger?—but mee honneur
Be un ting, et me un odre; me ſay nothing, but
Jerny—

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: leading Phill. Noble, Diana, Lyſſe, Siſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: ON my word, Madam, there was no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: But what then may it be?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Love, Madam, may,
And with ſuch fierceneſs drive on theſe deſignes
As will compaſs his ends—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Not always, Sir—
Brother, ſay what you pleaſe, but let me think:
Go out ſo ſuddenly, come home in dumps,
Have not a word to ſay; nay ſcarce afford
Common reſpect to your moſt worthy gueſts,
Is ſomewhat ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: He knows I am not his,
But your poor tenant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs,
That an odd buſineſs coming unexpected,
Has ſomewhat diſcompos'd me for the preſent,
For which I humbly beg your pardon, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: You have it;
But under favour, Sir, may we not know
What ſort of buſineſs 'twas you had in hand?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I hope it was no quarrel?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Was it not ſome gay Lady's aſſignation?
That Note that was deliver'd you laſt night,
In my minde, ſpoke ſo much.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: To tell the truth,
It was that very thing: I had intelligence
Of an amour.

div.stage: Enter Boy: whiſpers Diana, and Phill.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: What now, Sirrha?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Moving already, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: To th'next room.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Once more, Sir, you are welcome to this houſe,
And wiſh you quick ſucceſs in your addreſſes
Unto my Siſter, who already's inform'd
Of your own worth; and do believe that ſhe
Will not be o're-ſevere in the reception
Of your love beyond what's to be allowed
To th' modeſty of her Sex.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Your Generoſity
Is ſo ſurpriſing, that I'm to ſeek for words
To return you thoſe thanks that might proportion
With your civilities.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Y'are ſtill beforehand: my Siſters Portion, Sir,
Is yet entire, though I've had the misfortune
To looſe my ſhare of what we had inherited
From our Parents.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Had I any thoughts
That in the leaſt ſhould reflect upon intereſt,
'Twould render me unworthy the poſſeſſing
So rich a Jewel as that Lady, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Y'are too obliging, Sir,—who have we here?

div.stage: Sir Amorous leading Phill. and Diana ſinging.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Falla-la-la; Jerny Madmoiſell voſtre tres humble ſerviteur.
Neece! how is't, Girl? Monſieur je ſuis a vous.
Nephew! how doſt thou like this Peruque? ha!
This Trimming, Cravat, theſe Gloves, Sword and Belt?
The whole Apparel? hum? falla-la-la.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What the devil's the matter?
What your judicious Gravity approves,
I am not to conteſt—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Sure he is mad?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I've always told you, Nephew, that delays
Were ever of a dangerous conſequence;
And now y'are like to know it by experience.
You know how oft I've advis'd you to marry,
That I might ſee ſome likelyhood of Heirs
To be ſucceſſors to that fair Eſtate
I have acquired, by my aſſidual pains.
You have had time enough, yet nothing done:—
'Tis thoſe neglects of yours, have put me on
This great neceſſity of marrying
In theſe more riper years.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: The wench gueſt well—
I ſuppoſe, Sir, this is to try me with?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Miſtake not; I'm in earneſt, and in haſte.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Why, Sir, the Gentleman is young enough;
And his loſt time may eaſily be repair'd
(I'm of opinion) if it pleaſes him.
'Tis in his choice yet, to out-ſtrip you there.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Where, prithy? where?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I mean in Marriage, Sir,
My Knight takes me not yet; I dare no more—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I thought you knew the perſon, I proteſt.
I ſhall ſcarce marry theſe three or four daies,
And you may get a dozen wives by then;
But he muſt make good haſte, or come too ſhort.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: You ſay three or four daies?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Yes, thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Well, Sir, will you but yield that if I marry—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: The widdow Lovewealth? I'll put a ſpoke there.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: A Lady young and briſk, 'twixt this and when
You have appointed for your marriage-day,
You will—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I'll tell thee, nephew, what I'll do:
He that is firſt married of us two,
Shall bar the other from procuring Heirs
To my Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: A match, a match, e'faith.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: And if Sir Cogging, Sir, does get the day,
You'll declare him your Heir immediately?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What ſay you, Sir, to that?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: A match, a match;
I'll not deny you ſweet: you muſt run poſt?

sp.speaker: Nobl.
sp.l: 'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: We'll all be witneſs to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: And to my wedding alſo morrow-morn.
To which y'are all invited.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: How? ſo ſoon, Sir?
Y'allow'd a longer time.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Three or four daies?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, 'tis ſo; now make what haſte you can;
Whip, whip, and ſpur, y'had need, or lie behinde.
I'll ſtick to th' Contract; ſo Gentles, adieu.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What a mad Scene is this?

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: 'Tis unexpected—

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: And ſudden too, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Theſe the firſt news;
But now, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: E'en croſs his Match.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: But how is't to be done?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: W'are left i'th' dark:
Did we but know where he makes his addreſs,
There would be ſome hopes yet.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Sir, as for that,
I think I have a way which may ſucceed.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Prithy what is't?

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: You know, he has of late
Entertain'd a French ſervant.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: What of that?

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: The fool, who pretends kindneſſes to me,
Is doubtleſs privy to his Maſters love;
And if ſo, Sir, I make no queſtion then,
But to get knowledge of this ſecrecie.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: No better way.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Lyſſe, if thou do'ſt this,
Thou wilt deſerve our further care of thee.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Let me alone to worm out this French fellow;
Sir, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Come, chear up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, you may do ſo,
Who have aſſurances of your amours
By a Contract—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: A Contract ſay you, Sir?
(Curſe be the cauſe of this ſuſpicion in him.)
'Tis with my Parents then, never with me.
And likely enough that bargain's yet to make
Between the Gentleman you mean, and me.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: Brother, let me adviſe you ſtrait to go
To th' Lady Lovewealth; learn if 'twere the hopes
Of your Uncles Eſtate made her accept
The tender of your ſervices, or whether it be
A real affection does cauſe her to have
An eſteem for your perſon. If the laſt,
Inform her how y'are driven—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Not amiſs.
So now it works as I would have it, juſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Sir, if you pleaſe to honour me ſo far
As to lend me your company t'her houſe—

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: It muſt be then with theſe two Ladies leave.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: I'll but call by the way at the Roſe-tavern.

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: In the mean time, according to my promiſe,
I'll ſpeak two words at the School in next ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Very well, Sir, we'll meet at the Piazza
An hour hence.

sp.speaker: Noble.
sp.l: Till then, your ſervant, Sir.

div.head: SCENE III. The School-houſe.
div.stage: Kitty Noble, at a window; Shift in the ſtreet, in a fine Garb.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: NOw I'm a Prince again, in ſhew at leaſt.
Hem! hem!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Hiſt, hiſt.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: 'Tis I; is the coaſt clear?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: I'll look about—I ſee none we may fear.
Why did you ſtay ſo long?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: How does my Love?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: As well as hopes can make me,
And yet my thinks this day is cruel long.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: It draws towards its end.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Does the time hold?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Our work requires none.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: How ſhall we do
To get off in the dark? the Moon by twelve
Will yield us no more light.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: So I would hav't.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: It will be very dark: how ſhall I know
When you are come, or whether it be you?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Here, here; ſecure theſe half a dozen Keys:
When I am got up to the Ladder-top,
I'll in the Room, and ſeek you in the dark,
Where when you finde y'are taken by the hand,
Conclude 'tis I. By the help of theſe Keys
I'll open every door to th' Garden-ſide,
And that way we'll get off. Speak not a word,
Nor whiſper then.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: And where muſt we go then?
Not far, I hope.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Only to the Church-porch,
Where a Parſon ſhall wait to tye the Knot,
And then—

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Away, away, the Beldam comes.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Farewel till night.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: FOr theſe ſame reaſons, Sir, a ſtricter Eye
I've kept upon her actions than before;
And till ſome two months ſince, or thereabouts,
I could not finde ſhe had any commerce
Beyond theſe walls; which made me grant to her
A little more liberty than before.
But it could not laſt long: for one bright night,
About the hour of two, I heard a noiſe
On the back-ſide; I ſtole gently down ſtairs,
And there, you'll ſcarce believe't—

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Yes, I'll believe that ſhe has not her like.

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: I found the Gentlewoman
Letting down of a bucket full of ſtones
Into a Well.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: How's that, pray? full of ſtones?

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: I ſtood ſtill cloſe behinde,
And ſhe was ſo attentive at her work,
That ſhe perceiv'd me not: now mark, I pray!
Anon at th'other end of the Well-rope,
Up comes, what do you think, Sir? pray you gueſs.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: The Devil ſure.

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: No, Sir, but one of's friends,
Dreſt in a humane ſhape; a fine young man,
Who, as I thought, none but the Devil himſelf
Could have brought there. The Gallant ſpying me
Standing behinde, twitches the rope ſhe held,
And gently poiſes himſelf down again.
At this ſhe turns, and ſo eſpies me out.
You muſt needs think ſhe was much diſcompos'd
At the ſight of me?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: I know not what to think.

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: Wounderfully! ſhe in a laughing tone
Cries out, E'faith, you came i'th' nick of time,
Or elſe by this, I'd gin you the go-by.
With that, in a great laughter up ſhe runs,
Where having lock'd her ſelf, ſhe 'gan to ſing,
Oh! Love is a dilicate thing. I'th' morning
I viſited the Well, and in it found
Towards the middle, a window that did anſwer
Into a neighbouring Vault. I had a pump
Set in the place, to prevent for the future
Such like attempts. Seeing no remedy
But cloſe confinement of her in a Room
Under good locks and keys, I've mew'd her up,
Where ſhe does ſtill remain.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Cannot be helpt.
I pray let her not know of my return
Till I ſee you again. Till then, farewel.
I ſee 'tis eaſier the Ocean to ſpan,
Than keep by force a young maid from a man.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: Crosby, as he is going in, meets Siſs.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: NOw for to know my doom. Your Lady, Siſs?

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: She's gone to take the Air.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Come, let me in.
I ſhall grow angry elſe.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Here comes ſome Reſcue?

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Your obedient Servant, your Woman, Madam,
Deni'd you to me.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: She did nothing, Sir,
But what ſhe had in charge.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis like
(My fate's the harder) that I am ariv'd
Upon ſome newer intereſt.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your own
Was not ſo conſiderable, Sir, before,
Nor had it ſo much name you need to fear
That any ſhould ſucceed it.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: If there be any one dares own a favour
That's to my prejudice, let him look, Madam,
You hide him in your boſome, if he would not
Have this ſword through him.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Sir, you muſt preſcribe
No Laws to me: that perſon I ſhall chuſe
To throw my favours on, ſhall know to anſwer
Whatever heats you bring.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Why be it ſo.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: This care is over.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: A fair riddance, doubtleſs.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: This is not all, I have another plot,
To bring about my ends 'twixt Madam Phanny,
And this unworthy man, that I muſt do,
Or I've done nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Seriouſly, Madam,
I pitty that poor Lady at my heart,
She is ſo melancholy—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Where is ſhe now?

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: At her old trade of weeping.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I'll chear her up
E're long; if things do hit.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Pray Heavens they may.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Let's in, and there conſult with her about it,
Leſt we be troubled with this impertinent.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: CHampagne? dis de honneur es un Jewel
De grand eſtimation: it is de ſo pretious de ting
Dat mos no bee loſs; no, mos no be loſs:
Den mon revenge: Oh! very goot, very ſweet,
Par ma foy de hony is no ſo ſweet
As de revange to de Frenſh Vallet.
Derefor, par conſequent you de Eſtranger
Dat give de mee de paſ ope de face,
You moſs prepare for de dy, no remedee,
But Monſieur Champagne, mee mande pardon,
Mee aſk quarter, de grace mee no give:
Comment give box de Ear to mee perſon?
Ah! Jerny, ventre teſte, come nee I doon,
Dat mee cope de teſte, et preſent de it
To mee Maiſtreſſe Madamoiſelle Lyſſe.
Alon; mee no longre ſtay: point de quartier.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: How now? who's that you'll kill?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ha! Monſieur mon amy, begar mee be
Your very de humble Serviteur—mee very glad
De ſee de you ver vell, mee voul preſent de you
Vit de pint de vin.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: But my thinks you were grumbling
In an other dialect?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Es nothing, par ma foy:
Mee only repete de vers de la Comedy.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Perhaps y'are angry?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: No, no, ſur mon honneur.
Mee know you de jeſt, mee no angry, Mafoy:
You ſtrick de mee again if you de plaiſe,
Mee never tink de arm vit de amis.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Then fare you well, I've nothing more to ſay.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Humble Valet; Jerny, mort teſte non:
Mee no do vell, mee ſhoull have kill de him:
A ventre blew, mee voul call de him back.
sp.stage: Runs towards the door, then comes back.
sp.l: Dis fool pittee always take de mee
A contre temps: begar for de futur
Mee voul be cruel, batre, kill, cojel,
Maſſecre all to mee revange. Jerny,
Mee voul preſentement go ſend de him
Un ſhalange, but firſt mee vill viſit
Mee Maiſtreſſe Madmoiſelle Lyſſe, Jerny,
To give de mee de la valleur—Ah! pox de him.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: I had forgot that while y'are here, you ſhould
Preſent my humble ſervice to that Laſs
I met with you i'th morning, and let her know
I'll viſit here e're long: do not you fail.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Jerny?

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: What's that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ouy, ouy, dat is de ſay, iſs, iſs, preſentement,
Oll, oll, a little, mee do you de ſervice.
Dere no is vell.

div.stage: Exit Slye: Champ. looks after him a good while, then draws.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: Oh! thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Hum, um, um, Jerny; 'tis vell you go,
You make de ſcape, but mee caſh you agin
Un odre tim—mee voul extermin de you.
Oh! Madmoiſell, for de grand love de you,
Mee almoſt kill van, to, tree Rogue, juſt no.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: For love of me?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Is par la mort. Jerny.
Mee love de you tresfurieuſement.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: I, but how ſhall I know if this be true?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Sur mon honneur; mee engage mee honneur.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Were I but ſure—

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: O! mee voul tell de you?
Commande no, de mee de un ting,
Et mee voul do de ting: you ondreſtand?

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: That you'll do any thing I ſhall command?
Well, I'll trie you for once.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Come donc, allon.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: With whom is't that your Maſter is to marry?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Dat be begar de very grand ſecret;
Mee Maſtre vill no have de know, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: I thought as much: I ſee your love in this:
You love? you hang.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Madmoiſelle Lyſſe,pray come to mee, mee voul tell de you
De all; but you moſt be de very ſecret den?
Autrement—hum, um, um—

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Fear it not, man:
I'll be in this as ſecret as thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: De Mrs. de mee Mr. is un little Gentilhoman
In de Schoole, viſh mee Mr. take de away in de neet.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Who? Sir Amorous?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: No, no, Jerny, un odre:
Mee tell de you de all; mee have too Mr;
Premierement, de un dat is un Rogue;
Secondement, that Rogue pote de mee
To de odre dat is un fool—

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Sir Amorous you mean?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Juſt ſo, Jerny: no, mee Mr. de Rogue,
Voul all de ſheet, d'odre Mr. de fool,
Et take de venſh for him: begar, juſt ſo.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Is it this night?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Is, is, but moſs ſilance.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Here's cheat on cheat: hark, hark! ſomebody comes.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee voul come de ſee you after un hour.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Do ſo, be ſure you come: you'll finde me here.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Adieu, begar, de nexe tim mee ſee de you
Mee vill ſee if you be de goot fleſh; Jerny mee
Can no ſtay de longre for un homan.

div.head: SCENE III. Lovewealth's houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: PRew? go to my Cloſet, and fetch me the Letter
I now receiv'd from Sir Amorous Froſt.
It is both ſhort and ſweet. While I took care
How to diſmiſs Sir Coggin of his ſute,
There is proviſion made; I need no more,
When he's come in, but to ſhew him this Note:
Sure that will do't. How now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir Coggin, Madam,
Is new ſet down at door, deſires admittance
To your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why, bring him in—that's well:
I am prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, I have made bold—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You have ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Yet I hope the offence
Is not ſo great but that I may finde pardon?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis of that nature, Sir, as muſt not hope
To finde excuſe, much leſs a pardon for it.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Madam, I hope, 'tis not on my accompt
My friend is thus neglected by your Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No ſuch thing, Sir; if y'are rich you are welcome:
But for that Gentleman, (your friend you call)
That knows himſelf to be wretchedly poor,
Beyond all hopes, and yet pretend to me,
Is ſuch a thing as I muſt not forgive.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: 'Tis likely, Madam, that ſome Rival here
Is hapyer than I?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He is ſo, if more Rich:
That is the only thing, Sir, that ſways me.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, in the opinion of the general,
There are other things to be conſider'd
In the choice of a Huſband.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The Vulgar, ſay you?
That commonly runs falſe; and I'll be ſingular,
Sir, thus in ſhort: were you in full poſſeſſion
Of as fair an Eſtate as is your Rival,
Your perſon, Sir, might paſs muſter with me;
I like that well enough.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Come, come away;
For ſhame, Sir, do not ſpend one ſingle thought
Upon ſo intereſt a thing as this,
Who is a ſcandal to her gentler Sex.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Indeed! are you of that Religion too?
Here, Sir, read this, and then tell me your minde?

body.p: I hope you will attribute theſe few lines of advice to my diligent care of your Welfare, ſince they tend to no other end, than the giving you notice that I am in minde to have Heirs of my own getting, and leave my Nephew to his Ingenuity. I make no queſtion but you know my meaning: So conclude,

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Your Uncle has been too quick for you here.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, ſince it is ſo, yet give me leave
To congratulate my Rival e're I go.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, To ſpeak the truth, I had intelligence
He would be here this day; but yet, not come.
I'th' evening, Sir, if you pleaſe to be here,
You'll witneſs our Contract.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: And Marriage too?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: If he has a minde to't.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, I'll come.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Your Friend too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Your thrifty Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So much for that: now ſhall I think it long
Till my new Lover comes. I wonder what
His Compliment will be?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: By relation, Madam,
He cannot ſay, as a body ſhould ſay,
As one ſhould ſay, boh! to a Gooſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Go to:
How goes the day?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: Madam, on its decline.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And not come yet?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A ſtrange Gentleman, in as ſtrange a dreſs,
Madam, demands acceſs unto your Ladyſhip,
Both for himſelf, his mouth, his man, and dog.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What's this thou ſay'ſt?
Admit him here.
Sure this is he, by the Meſſage he ſent.
I dread his coming in, who juſt before
Wiſh'd he were here: I muſt receive him now.
It is too late to think.

div.stage: Clay takes his Compliment from Per. pins it to his Hat, comes up to the Lady, makes a Leg, then falls back again, hems, ſpits, and Coughs; blows his Noſe on the ground, then wipes it on his ſleeve.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Come here, poor Rogue.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Now minde your buſineſs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.p:
Madam, ſuper Excellent, and the ſole ſupreme Miſtris of my ſober Paſſions, (hem, pat the Dog) paron—hum—pardon, that my peregrine ſelf intreats the Mixifick effects of the ſweet Influentials of your, of your,—your—Loxogonoſ—phe—ri-cal Intuition. You ſublime Lady alone, are able to nurce up this— (hem again.) (a pox of theſe hard words) ex—exta—extatickal embryo of your more than thrice ſupedaneous Admirer. (hem again.
Give me leave ſuper Mundaine Lady, to ſupplicate at the (nownow again) ſub-t-e-r-ter-ſel of your feet; and pardon him who ſubſcribes himſelf your ſlave, as far beneath your pitty, as a Myrmidonial Inſect to higheſt of Stairs; no, Stars I mean.

div.stage: (Ʋnpins the Paper, gives it to Per.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.p: So much for the Compliment Clunch, want it well done? efecks, 't has made me ſweat. This thing call'd wooing, is a moſt peſt'lant thing. Lady, if you'd have more, I've brought my mouth with me, d'you ſee, to ſpeak for me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, in few words, y'are welcome to my houſe.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: It is not quite ſo big as our new Barn:
What thinks thou, Clunch?

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Yea, thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: There's nothing can be more ridiculous:
'Tis the meer abſtract of impertinencie;
Worſe cannot be.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am glad to hear that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: How do you like my Dog?
sp.stage: (Holds up his Dog to the Lady.
sp.l: Do you ſee, Madam, en't it a fine thing?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Oh! very fine indeed, and nothing finer.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Come hither, Tray? what do you think's his name?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why Tray I think.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Efecks y'are in the right;
sp.stage: Clay ſets him down, ſets Tray in another chair, leaves the Lady ſtanding.
sp.l: That you ſhould gueſs, d'you ſee, ſo well at firſt!
Did ſhe not, Clunch?

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Yea, yea, what was't you ſaid?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Effecks, I'm glad to ſee you well: ſit down.
Ho! fetch a ſtool for my Lady to ſit.
sp.stage: Clay plays with the Dog, whiſtles ſo loud, be drowns all that they ſay.
sp.l: Mouth, do you talk to my Lady a little,
While I play with my Dog.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am commanded
Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Heavens deliver me from this Impertinent!

div.stage: Per. and the Lady as in diſcourſe, while Clay is ſtalking up and down whiſtling, &c.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oye, oye, let him alone for Compliments.
I ſtoo-her, mouth: he'll give you your belly full
Of Compliments, and Courtſhip, and what not?
I'll play him 'gainſt any in Town or Country
At either of thoſe Weapons for a great.
Oye, ſtick cloſs to her man, oye, oye, look on.
I know 'tis all for me he ſpeaks to you:
For why? he is my mouth, are you not, mouth?
How do you like him, Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: 'Tis all the better for me ſtill, I cry.
I pray ſit down. This London, Lady mine,
Is a chargeable place. Nay, look on me;
sp.stage: Lady minds not Clay, looks on Per.
sp.l: He is only to ſpeak, not to look on.
What do you think 't has coſt me, do you ſee,
Since I'm in Town, on me, on Clunch, and Tray?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What is't you ſaid?

div.stage: Clay pulls her, to make her hear.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Well, Lady, for this bout
I will not poſe you in't; but in a lump
'T has coſt me juſt ſeven Nobles, d'you ſee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What perſon, Sir, is this you have brought with you?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: It is my Mouth; I told you ſo before,

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Gentleman, d'you ſee, that will ſpeak you—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And are you ſure he is a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Our Neighbour Airy told me ſo, I'm ſure;
And this I know, ſhe would not lye for th'matter.
I tell you once more, he's a Gentleman
Every inch on him: do but try him elſe;
He'll give you, do you ſee, your belly full.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: This works for me beyond imagination.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Nay, but pray hear me out: I brought him here,
That in caſe you lov'd Compliments, d'you ſee,
A ſhould ſit your turn, Lady, t'a Cow's thumb,
As one ſhould ſay: for, for my part,
I naturally hate theſe Compliments.
Look on him, Lady, pray.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A good preſence.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Effecks I'm woundy dry: Clunch fetch two Pots
To make my Lady drink.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, uſe my Cellar:
It is the fitteſt place for ſuch a beaſt.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Efecks a match, a match; come hither Tray.
Nay, well all go: I'll lead in Tray, d'you ſee?
And you, Clunch hand my Lady: As for Mouth,
He is only to talk.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Hands off.

div.stage: Clunch offers to take the Lady by the hand, ſhe flies off. Exeunt Clay and Clunch.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Chuſe chub.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Now I begin t'abhor that fooliſhneſs
Which poſſeſt me ſo late. I am juſtly puniſhed
For my covetouſneſs; plainly foreſee
I ſhall become a laughing-ſtock to all.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam, if that—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, anſwer me firſt:
Are you a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I am ſo, Lady.
But Madam, give me leave to let you know
My miſeries, the croſſneſs of my Stars,
Thoſe fatal Influences did preſide
At th'hour of my Birth—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What, Sir, can make you
So unhappy a man, as you endeavour
To repreſent your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis this:
That being extracted of a Gentile ſtock
Honourably deriv'd, have been imbu'd
With a proportion'd breeding to my Birth,
I ſhould want that great Idol of the world,
A futable Eſtate to all thoſe things
I have but newly mention'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A comely man;
Me thinks I am concern'd at his relation:
Pray, Sir, how long have you known Mr. Clay?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Only ſince morning, Madam, have I ſeen
This man poſſeſt with that great lump of treaſure
Which renders him ridiculous to the world;
While the hundred part of that vaſt Eſtate
Might intitle ſome worthy gentleman
To your conſideration.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Would I were certain
This perſon were of a Gentile extraction.
When're I caſt my Eye upon his preſon,
Me thinks I do him wrong to queſtion it.
I feel ſomewhat within me takes his part,
That will not let me reſt, but whiſperes ſtill
Unto my heart, This man's to be prefer'd
With his bare virtue, before that other thing
With all its wealth. Come, Sir, we'll in an ſee
What is become of Mr. Timothy Clay
And his followers.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam, I'll wait upon you.

div.stage: (Per. takes the Lady by the hand, Exeunt.)

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: CHampagne, this is the night which is deſign'd
For my Amorous Theft: you muſt aſſiſt
With ſecrecie, be ſure?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Secret, Jerny, no feere for dat:
Mee be all de ſecret, mee have de ſecret
To kill the Ratts, de Fleeſe, de Mooſs, de Tick;
De ſecret to make de Money, to make de Charme,
To caſh de prity Venſh; de ſecret de make de looſe
De grate Belee, de botte ſecret, de Jerny—
De ſecret—to runn avay vit your monee and cloſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Noting, noting, mee only repette all de mee ſecret.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Againſt the time, provide your ſelf for action
With uſeful arms, ſuch as you handle beſt.
'Tis like we may imploy them—do you ſee,
'Tis a dangerous attempt?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Oh! let mee come.
Begar, if dare be de bougre, de Rogue dat vill
Make de reſiſtance, me voul come ca give
De him un grand poſh—den vit come ca kill de him.
Preſentement, ha—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Hold, ſure th'art mad?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Is begar, ven you ſpeak de feet, mee be mad, de Kill de all.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Beſides, you muſt provide you a diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Diſquiſe: ho! very goot, no fere for dat,
Mee voul diſquiſe as moſh redicul as de you.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Come, let's hear how?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee voul go in de eſtable, take de little horſe,
Mee voul kill de him, den mee voul take de his
Skinn et pote upon de mee, den mee voul keek, and
Beet et Cree whin hin: humrfl. is no excellant?
Diſquiſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Yes, but I looſe my horſe by th' bargain, man.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Den mee do autrement, mee take de his ſkinn,
And no kill de him; den ven me don vitt de
Skin, mee put de it ope de horſe again:
Is no dat good, no?

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Still I ſhould looſe my horſe.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Pox de horſe: you get de Madmoiſell? is no better.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: We'll think on't, man: This night's to prove
To me a night of Pleaſures, and of Love.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Young Airy ſolus, in Riding habit.
div.l: DIck Airy, th'art in London once again;
And now, what's to be done? I know not faith:
I'll examine my Pockets, ſee what's left
Of Lands, Chattels, and Goods, Money and all;
All I have in the world is in this place.
Let's ſee, what have we here? juſt ſeven Guinies;
I'll to the Ordinary, there I'll try
Whether theſe ſeven pieces I have left
Are good breeders or not; if not, why then
I ſhall but loſe what would do me no good
To keep, except 'twere more: however, then
I ſhall be throughly clear'd of that ſmall ſtock
Which never did me good ſince the firſt hour
My Father left it me. How he came by't
I know not; let that paſs: then will I try
What I can do of my own ſelf to live:
What know I but Fortune would prove more kinde
Were this gone alſo?
Unwilling peradventure I ſhould owe
My happineſs to any thing but ſhe.
I'll try her once; Fortune, an't be thy will
To have me looſe this Gold, yet help me then,
Meerly out of ſtark kindeneſs and pure love.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: QUe dis honneur es un fooliſh de ting!
Et que un box de Ear cauſe moſh trouble!
Ho moſh un vaillant man, moſt have de buſineſs?
For un box de Ear mee moſt now kill de him
Dat give it de mee; it is que de forſt time
He ſtrick de mee, for all dat he moſt dee.
But mee is de opinion dat is very de ſimple
To go de feet vit ſimplement de ſhart,
Becaus der be veree grat many places
To kill de man, and ſo de ſend de him
To de Antipodes. Der is de Hart,
De Livre, de Kiddeneis, de Longs, de Gots,
De Artere, de Vains, de Nerfs, et d'Eſtomach;
Derfor, as un prudant et vaillant home,
Mee have prepared de arms cap eſpee.
Mee have de very good parade, contre de Tierce,
De Cart, de Coup four; et contre de Back-ſword:
As par example, mee ſee mee enemy
Juſt befor de mee, mee draw, ha! ders for you.
Begar me ſtick de him juſt in de panſſe:
Jerny, mee parre vell? a ha! do you go back?
Alon, ventre Jerny, der to you head:
Ha! if mee no go back, mee have de hol
Juſtement in de hart, you paye for dat!
Ha! very goot, par ma foy: mee kill de Eye!
Bon, Jerny, mee kill de odre: O! blind man?
You moſt, Jerny, have de dog et de bell.
Hellas! Monſieur Champagne, mee aſke pardon:
No Jerny, no moſt dee: He! pardon—no pardon.

div.l: Begar Madamoiſelle you come de very goot tim.
Autrement me have kill de Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: What? who? where? why?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Par ma foy is juſt go.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee voul go feſh de him,
And kill de him for your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: No, good Champagne—

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Maiſtre Champagne, Jerny.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Then good Mr. Champagne,
Let him live for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Vell, live den, car Madmoiſelle
sp.stage: Looks out, as ſpeaking to ſome body—
sp.l: Vill have de it ſo.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Well, have you got the name?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Begar, mee know de all mee voul tell de you,
But you love de mee very vell den,
And let mee do de little ting—

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Nothing, nothing begar, mee only ſay
You have de mee for your Oſban, is no?

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: I promiſe here, Champagne, to Marry you.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Aye! Monſieur Champagne?

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: Monſieur Champagne, I mean.
At the ſame hour your Rogue-Maſter ſhall wed
That Miſtriſs he's about.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Toſhe de hand:
Mee tell de you in ſecret—

div.stage: Enter Sir Cog. Phill. Nob. Dian. Siſs.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I ſuppoſe, Sir, that you are now return'd
From th'aſſignation?
What did the Lady ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, I will inform you punctually
Of all that paſt between us. The Lady come
At the appointed place, cauſed the Chair
She was in to be ſtopp'd, and thus began.
There is a Lady not far from this place,
Of Beauty, Youth, Birth, and Eſtate to boot,
Not inferiour to the rich Lady Lovewealth,
Has ſuch Eſteem, Affection, if not Paſſion,
Or rather Love for your perſonal worth,
As cannot be expreſs'd in leſſer terms
Than making you her Huſband.
Sir, you muſt know,
This night ſhe does intend in a diſguiſe,
To Maſcarade it at the Lady Lovewealth—
Where I'll be ſure to accompany her.
Madam, here's all
That has paſt 'twixt the Lady and my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I finde I am not in the leaſt ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Well Lyſſe, what news now?

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: None, Sir, but good.
Theſe were his words, as well as he could ſpeak,
Or I them underſtand. Mee Maſtre's Miſtriſs is a
Young Lady whoſe name is Mrs. Kitty Noble.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: How, Kitty Noble, ſay'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.p: This night, at three, my Maſter de Rogue and I ſteel her away, and cheat mee Maſter the fool of his fine Miſs by a Ladder of Ropes, out of a window next to the Garden-wall at the Boardingſchool in our own ſtreet. He added, that this Maſter was to be diſquis'd like a Woman, and he he knew not yet. This did he jabber in his Gibberiſh tone.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Come, come, fear nothing, Sir, all will do well;
This works as I could wiſh: your aſſignation
At the Lady Lovewealth once at an end,
If you do not ſucceed, we'll watch th' old Knight,
And ſeize upon that moſt villanous Rogue
That ſets him on meerly for his own ends,
As we may clearly ſee beyond diſpute
By Lyſſe's late intelligence: we know the hour—
And there's no fear but to compaſs our ends.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, if that—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Sir, I hope you'll excuſe
My abſence this night from the Lady Love wealths?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: And do you leave me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: She is not well.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I ſhall wiſh you good ſport, and good ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Come Siſter, you'll along?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Yes, ſhe ſhall go,
And Lyſſe too.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Come, come, let's looſe no time.
Madam, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Servant, Lady.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Phill. and Siſs.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Haſt thou got all things ready?

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Madam, I have.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Cupid proſper and crown this laſt nights work!

sp.speaker: Siſs,
sp.l: watch their goings forth, and in what dreſs
Sir Coggin is accoutred; and when th'are gone,
Advertiſe me, that we may after them
With diligence. Surely it is impoſſible
I ſhould be known in a Torch-bearer's habit,
With ſuch a Maſk as will hide all my face?
Thou being the Lady too?

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs,
That this change put upon them, will help much
To your concealment.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: It will: be gone; make haſte.

div.l: Who's this that knocks? I would not be ſeen now:
I'll hide the light, and then let them in.
Who's there?

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: 'Tis more than I know yet.

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: I can't help that. Sir Coggin? is it you?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: I'm glad I've met you, Sir, though in the dark:
I have but ſome few words—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Your buſineſs, pray?

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: My buſineſs is but ſhort: Mr. Crosby,
From whom I came, has deſired me to ſay
You had not, Sir, that Title in Phill. Airy,
Or any of that worthy Ladies Virtues,
As he himſelf has, and does hold by right;
And on the ſame accompt, deſires to ſee you
In the Piazza with your ſword in hand,
At ſix this morning.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I'll wait upon him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: It will be requiſite you take a friend;
Your Rival honours me.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: That ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Brave.
sp.l: I am your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Sir, I am yours.

div.l: Now am I challeng'd: O! here comes my Second.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: I come to tell you that the coaſt is clear.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Come, let us to the Coach, and as we go
I'll tell thee the beſt Jeſt that ever was.

div.head: SCENE III. Lovewealth's houſe.
div.l: Lady Lovewealth, Per. Clay, Clunch, Tray, Prew.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: A Vadds, now, do you ſee, my head does ake
Like any wild-fire? hark you, my Lady?
Now, do you keep of all theſe ſorts of Liquors
In your own Cellar, all the year about?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Yes, yes, why not?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Why then y'are woundy rich.
What's your name, Prew?

sp.speaker: Prew.
sp.l: My name is Prudence, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I prithy look my head.

div.stage: Sets himſelf on a Chair, his legs over the Ladies lap, and his dog in his. Lady riſes in anger, diſcourſes with Per.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No fleſh and bloud
Can bear this inſolence.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: 'Tis very cold;
Fecks we'l to Blind-man's-bluff: 'twill heat us all.
Clunch ſhall be hid.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Not I; I know your tricks.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I am waggiſh ſometime, Lady, d'you ſee,
And he is wary of me: come, I'll hide.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: I'll blinde you then.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: No, my Lady ſhall do't.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: No, no, d'you mark me, I'll have no ſuch cheating.

sp.speaker: Clay.
