sp.l: So, o-brave Clunch, that calls my Lady cheat!
Th'art ſo miſtruſtful—come along ſimpleton:
Hold, hold, Clunch, not ſo hard.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Is it well now?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Oye, oye, d'you ſee, I'll have no goings out.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: No, no, come on.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Heavens! what will this be?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A cure I hope to your brains and my fortune.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Have at you Clunch; you do not clap your hands.
I warrant you this was Clunch. I taught him that.
I'll fit him for't.

div.stage: Clunch lays himſelf down, Clay falls over him.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Ods wowks, what have we here?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I'll tell you what, if I do catch you, Clunch.
Oh! have I caught you now, Clunch? Devil, Oh!

div.stage: Catches the Wheel barrow, runs away crying.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: What's this inſolencie for?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: But Maſcarades.
How his anger •• comes him? all he doth
Has ſo much grace—

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: I would I were a whom.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I would to Heaven thou had'ſt never been here.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Had I know, Lady, that your houſe was haunted,
I'd ne're a come ſo far to marry you.
What do I know, d'you ſee, but when we two
Were in one bed minding of ſomewhat elſe,
We ſhould have theſe Hobgobblings come to us,
And ſo mar all our ſport? Pray now how long
Has your houſe been haunted? what ſay you Mouth?
Won't they hurt Tray? nor Clunch? nor you? nor me?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Obſerve, they dance.

div.stage: After the Dance exeunt all the Maskers, but the Wheel-bar.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Th'are merry Devils fecks.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: Hy-day; more Devils yet?

div.stage: Enter Sir Amorous and Champagne in a Spaniſh Garb.
Champ. dances a Saraband, or Antique.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Whow! Hell's broke looſe.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Sir, if you dare put confidence in me,
Here I proteſt that in every reſpect
She is to Madam Phill. Airy equal,
If not to be prefer'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Well, Madam, ſince
I muſt not hope to ſee the Lady's face
Before I've given my hand, and muſt confeſs
You have been juſt in all y'have hitherto
Declar'd to me; my life and fortunes both,
I put into your hands, to diſpoſe of
As you ſhall beſt think fit.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Then give me leave
To ſpeak you at this time a happy man:
Some minutes, Sir, will make you ſay the ſame.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Madam, I am all faith.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Give me your hand,
To diſpoſe with your heart, as I think fit.

div.stage: She gives it to Phill. he ſtarts at the habit.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What, wedded to a boy? Madam, what's this?
Sure I am not ſo tame as you imagin,
To have this put upon me thus?

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Now, Madam,
It is time to diſcover.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: How, Madam, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: But ſhew your face, then you clear all ſuſpicion
In this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Will this, Sir, ſerve the turn?.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Heavens!
But once more let me gaze; my happineſs
Is ſo wonderful great, I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: What think you now?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: What think I Madam?
I cannot think, nor ſpeak, nor ſee, nor hear.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Peace, not a word: hold up the humour ſtill,
That we may not diſturb my Brother in his Amour.
Your Siſter and I, Sir, will borrow your Coach
While you two catch the Old Knight in's own trap:
Then we'll expect you home. Run in no danger.
Remember y'are mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Be pleaſed, Madam,
I'th' interim, to partake of our Banquet?

div.stage: They open the Wheel-barrow, take out the Sugar-plums that lie at top, throw them about, then preſent the sweet-meats to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: 'Tis likely, Sir, you know not your own minde?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: I'll give it you under what Oath you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: That, Sir, perhaps is too ſerious a thing
For any thing you mean. And then, beſides,
Do but conſider our young acquaintance, Sir,
Which is not a month old.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: An Age in Love!
Who with induſtrious wings ſhould leave behinde
The formal hours, nor is our meeting, Madam,
To be aſſign'd to any portion of them,
Since it was meant as ſoon as we took breath;
And is but reconcil'd to accidents
That make it up.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: A new Philoſophy?
Well, Sir, go on.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: A mumble, Clunch?
Hye Tray, there; mumble boys.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: And ſhould we add to it (I mean that time)
A cheap account of years, they cannot give
The more authority to my Vows, nor wrong
The honourable Favours you may ſhowre
Upon your Servant. Theſe things well conſider'd,
You muſt conclude, Madam, tis with a form,
An idle cuſtom, you would now comply
Againſt my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Well, Sir, in ſhort,
Since by my Brother I'm inform'd you are
A perſon much deſerving, and that beſides
I'm wholly guided by him in this choice,
You promiſing ſo fair, henceforth you'll have
More than a Miſtriſs in title of me;
And for the future, 'tis like I'it command:
Think how you can obey.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Obſequiouſly;
Nothing within the circle of my power
To be exempted, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: On theſe conditions,
I may be bold, Sir, to give you my hand.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: And I to ſeal them, Madam,
On the white authors of my happineſs.

div.stage: (Kiſſes her hand. Sir Cog. preſents the Heart to Phill. other parts to the other Ladies.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Sure, Sir, that's done already, is it not?
Or I have loſt by th' bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo, Madam;
And this is meerly Emblematical.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Now for ſome Hyppochras!

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: White or red, Madam?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Either, Sir, both.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: How do you like your Liquors?

div.stage: Wreſt an arm, draw Claret, draw white as from the Bladder.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: They are good.
I'll try your ſkill once more; ſome Jelly now:
What are his brains turn'd to that ſubſtance too?

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: They are the kindeſt Devils that e're I ſaw;
Are they not, Clunch?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: my Brother plies it cloſe;
I hope he will carry the Widow.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Whoe're you are accept my hearty thanks
For your moſt pleaſant and ſeaſonable paſtimes.
No longer between intereſt and love
Shall my heart wavering be, but chuſe
The latter for his god, and with diſdain
Renouncing Pluto, Cupid's ſlave remain.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I. Covent-garden.
div.stage: Young Airy▪ ſolus in the dark.

sp.speaker: Y. Airy.
sp.l: WHy this is well: when things are at the worſt,
They commonly do mend; ſo may my fortune.
But firſt let me be ſure there's none o'th'dregs
Of the late ſtock behinde, leſt that a little
Of the old leaven ſhould ferment that Maſs
Which is to come; ſend it after the reſt
To th' Devil head-long: what have I got here?
sp.stage: Airy ſearches his Pockets, finds a Guiny, weighs it in's hand.
sp.l: Another Devil in a golden dreſs?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: No, Sir, Heavens defend, I am the Parſon
You have appointed to marry you this night.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.l: What's this you ſay?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That five hundred a year,
And a young handſome Wife i'th' bargain, Sir,
Should make you diligent, and looſe no time.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.l: Hold Fortune; not ſo faſt, leſt I ſhould ſurfeit.
How, fawning of a ſudden? Here, take this.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir; there needs not ſo much haſte;
I could a ſtayed till the buſineſs were done.
Sir, I'll be gone, and wait at the Church-porch,
Where firſt you did appoint me for to be:
There I'll expect you both to tye the Knot.

sp.speaker: Airy.
sp.l: Hiſt! hiſt!—the Devil I gave him but now
sp.stage: Kitty lets fall the Lander of ropes on him, 〈…〉 .
sp.l: Has carried him away, and with him all
The budding hopes I had—How now? what's this?
A Rope? 'tis ſo: ready faſtned for uſe?
I thank thee Fortune however for this,
But beg your pardon if I ſlight your favour.
A Ladder of Ropes? there's ſomething in the winde,
Some Lover's aſſignation, or ſome thieves;
It may be either. Should it be the laſt,
It were but charity to warn the houſe.
If't proves the firſt, as probably it may,
As far as I can gueſs, by th' late diſcourſe
I had with him my Devil took away;
Why may not I expect from a Ropes end,
What was deni'd me by all other means,
An end of all my miſeries at once,
As many finde? I'll up and try th'Event,
Whatſoever it be.

div.stage: Enter▪ Sir Am. Shift, Champ. Per.
After, Enter Nob. Cog. and Slye.
They grope in the dark for the Ladder.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: We muſt grope for this Ladder in the dark.

div.stage: Theſe 3 lines are ſpoken while Airy gets up the Ladder.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Go you one way, and I'll another take.
And he that findes the Ladder firſt, gets up.

div.stage: Gets up the Ladder into the window, feels out Kitty, takes her by the hand; ſhe ſeems ſurprized.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: I'm glad y'are come;
I thought you very long: is the Miniſter
At the Church-porch?

sp.speaker: Airy,
sp.l: Peace, peace.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Come, let me lead,
I know the way o'th' houſe better than you.
Once more remember what a wiſe you get,
Young, Rich, and, though I ſay't, handſome to boot:
I hope, Sir, you'll deſerve this happineſs,
sp.stage: He anſwers not, but Kiſſes her hand.
sp.l: By your tender love to me.

div.stage:
Sir Amorous findes firſt the Ladder, get up; Noble finds it next, ſtands aſide of it holding it in his hand: Shift finds it next, goes to get up; Noble ſeizes on him, gives him to Sir Cog. and Slye
〈…〉 Sir Amorous ſtumbles in the dark, raiſes the 〈◊〉 a noiſe within, an outcry of Thieves.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Jerny, mee ſave mee Modres ſhild; adieu.

div.stage: Thinking to run away, runs againſt a wall, falls backwards.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Madam, we are undone if you come not.
I beg it on my knees, make haſte away,
Or ſay you will not go: what, not a word?

div.stage: Ranges about within: Diſpatch to Madam Kitty's Chamber there.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Why, Madam, Madam? Oh! Heavens, ſhe's gone;
And I'm ſo frighted, that I cannot move.
They come, and I'm undone—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Break down the door, it muſt be there.
Sieze on her there: what's this? a man apparell'd
In a womans dreſs? a pure Rogue this!

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: But where is Madam Kitty all this while?

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Not to be found.

sp.speaker: 2 Serv.
sp.l: What a confuſion's here?
Come along, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Thieves in diſguiſe of Watchmen with a Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Thief.
sp.l: Stand: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Here, here, ſeize on theſe Thieves, and hold them faſt.
I took them in the act, robbing the School-houſe.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Impudent Rogue!

div.stage: (As Nob. and Sir Cog. offer to reſiſt, they fall on um and diſarm them.
Enter Women, with ſpits; forks, &c. bringing Sir Am.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.l: Come, come, bring forth the Thief:
Which is the Watch?

sp.speaker: Thieves.
sp.l: Here, here; What, more Rogues yet?

sp.speaker: Watchman.
sp.l: Stand: Who goes there?
Call the Conſtable ho.

div.stage: The true Watch whiſper buſily together.

sp.speaker: Thieves.
sp.l: We are the Watch.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: Come, away with them there, to th' Juſtice, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: To Juſtice Froſt we'll go.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Yes, there I'll go.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: No, Sirs, you ſhall go to ſome other Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: To Juſtice Frost.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Yes, yes, they ſhall go there.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.l: But I ſay no.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: What Ward are you of, friends?

sp.speaker: Thieves.
sp.l: Of Covent-garden Watch.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Seize on the Rogues,
W'are Covent-garden Watch: how, counterfeits?
We'll teach you t'faleyfie the King's Majeſty
I'th' perſon of his conſtable and Watchmen.
Along, along, to Sir Amorous Frost with them.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: This works well now.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: As well as heart could wiſh.

div.head: SCENE II. Lady Lovewealth's houſe.
div.stage: Enter Lady Lovewealth, Per. leading her. Clay, Clunch, and Tray.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: WEll, well, ſince it is ſo, I'll e'ne march off;

So Lady fare you well: com •
Tray, come Clunch,
Come mouth, we'll home.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, I muſt beg your pardon,
If I make bold to detain this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: To teach you Compliments.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For that ſame purpoſe,
And frequently to practice Courtſhip with him,
That I may be expert.

sp.speaker: Clay.
sp.l: Practice, expert.
She begins well already—e'ne ſtay with her.
For as well, in our Town, wee have no need
Of Complimenters, nor of Courtiers neither.
There will I in all haſte, ſo fare you well.

sp.speaker: Clunch.
sp.l: There will I in all haſte, ſo fare you well.
Come, Tray, bid them farewel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I muſt return you, Sir, thanks for thoſe pains
Which you have taken to render me ſenſible
Of my late folly, my covetous minde:
Therefore in gratitude to your civilities,
I give you this aſſurance to be yours.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And I, Madam, with a moſt ſervent Love,
And moſt obſequious Services? will pay
My offerings to this Altar every day.

div.head: SCENE III. Sir Am. his houſe.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: BRing in the Priſoners there, make room before.

div.stage: Enter Champ. laughs at his Maſter. Exit.
div.l: Come, where's his worſhip? let him know w'are here.
div.stage: Enter Croſby. Noble ſteals off; Croſby would retire, the Watchmen detain him.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: No, no, we know your tricks.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Gentlemen, look all to your Priſoners there.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: Let's count them over.

div.stage: They count, and reckon Croſby among them.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: Th'are right, th' are right.

sp.speaker: Crosb.
sp.l: Gentlemen, you miſtake, I'm none o'th number;
Meerly Curioſity did bring me here.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: I think he came in ſince.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Then let him go.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Viſh is de Conſtable?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Here, here, I am.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Mee Mr. bidd mee aſke de you for de grate Teef
In de humans clos, he vill anſer for de him.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Here, here a is; I warrant an old Thief:

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: By your leave, friends, you know me, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: My honeſt Landlord?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I'm glad to ſee you well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: This Gentlewoman, Mrs. of the School,
Says, that through a miſtake was all this ſtir:
She finds nothing amiſs in all her houſe,
And therefore is come hither to treat
For the liberty of theſe Gentlemen:
It is not ſo?

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: 'Tis as the Gentleman ſays.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Mr. Conſtable, a word with you in private.

div.stage: Brings him aſide, whiſpers to him, gives him money.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: The Juſtice is very long.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: He was aſleep;
'Tis like they could not wake him o'th' ſudden.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Come, Gentlemen, let's go; I'm certifi'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: I hope they'll give us ſomething though to drink?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: There, honeſt friends; good night.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Nob. Sir Cog. Croſt. and Slye.
sp.l: Good Mrs. Croſtitch, where found you my Siſter?

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: Paſſing by our houſe, as from that ſtreet
That leads to Covent-garden, a Gentleman
Leading her by the hand, by chance a glimpſe
Of a neighboring light diſcover'd her to me.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: What did ſhe ſay?

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: Why, Sir, that ſhe was married
To that Gentleman; which he own'd to be true.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: She is undone for ever! quite undone!
Where is ſhe now?

sp.speaker: Croſt.
sp.l: Sir, ſhe is at my houſe,
Where ſhe ſaid ſhe would ſtay till you came to her.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Go and be with her, pray, until I come.
This buſineſs manag'd well, Sir, may be worth
A thouſand pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: That I muſt do.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: I'll to my Siſter go, examine her;
While you'll do well to go to the old man
And try what you can do, while he is yet
In's pannick fears.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Be ſure I'll do my beſt.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: I'll take my Siſter with me to your houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: My houſe is yours, you know; Now muſt I go
To the old Knight with a moſt griveous ſtory,
No leſs than Burglary and rape i'th' Gaſe,
And thoſe with aggravations—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Nephew, undone!
Undone for ever in my Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: I hope not ſo, dear Sir, though had enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: What's become of the reſt? Oh! fatal hour!

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Sir, by my means convey'd out of the way,
Not far from hence.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Now Child, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Sir, for the preſent I have ſtopp'd all proceedings,
Though 'twill break out again.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: Too ſoon, I fear.
Well Nephew, though 'tis late, I ſee my fault,
And moſt deſervedly am puniſh'd for't:
I put my ſelf, and Reputation both,
Into your hands; preſerve them both as yours.
I ſhall requite you, and in conſideration
O'th' wrong I would of late have done you, Nephew,
I will allow you, during my whole life,
A thouſand pounds a year; and at my death,
The whole reverſion of all my Eſtate.
Let's in, and there I'll confirm the Deed to you
Before ſufficient witneſſes, till I can
Get the Writings drawn up.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Honoured Sir,
My life and honour ſhall for evermore
Stand between you and any ſort of danger.
That no time may be loſt, I'll inſtantly
To th'company, and take upon my ſelf
The whole adventure. I hope I ſhall finde friends
To get me off for ſome ſmall ſum of money.
It will be ſaid of me, it was my youth.
Thus, Sir, your Reputation will be ſafe,
Your Perſon out of danger, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: I inſtantly
Will ſend to have the Writings drawn up,
With all the haſte that may be.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: Sir, good night.

div.head: SCENE IV. Sir Cog. houſe.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: PRethy, dear heart, content thy ſelf a while;
Th' appointed hour was between five and ſix,
And 't has but juſt ſtruck five.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: My deareſt friend,
Pardon my Jealouſies—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Be chearful then;
I'll lay my life 'twill do.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: Should your plot fail,
I were undone paſt all hopes of repair.
Is the Parſon come yet?

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Yes, long ago;
Waits in the Chamber next my Ladies cloſet,
Has but cold comfort on't.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: He's in the dark.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: H'as neither fire, nor light,
And is lock'd up.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Come Siſs, along with me to the Piazza.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Madam, I cannot fight.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: No matter, Wench,
I'm ſtout enough for both.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.l: Without a ſword?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I'll leave you, Madam; you muſt have no light:
Let me alone to put the Change upon him.
Here comes ſome company, retire quick.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Well, Madam Siſter, have you done your do?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Faith, dear Siſter, not yet; but one plot more,
And then no more: Where's your Brother, Madam,
And Mr. Noble?

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Not yet return'd, you ſee;
But ſure they'll not be long.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Well, I muſt go,
I ſhall not ſtay 'bove half an hour, at moſt.
I hope at my return to finde all here.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Madam, how dare you venture all alone
At this unſeaſonable hour?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I fear no Colours!

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: This new Siſter of mine is a mad thing.
What ſtrange things ſhe has acted here of late!
And ſtill with good ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Lyſſe.
sp.l: She has her ends.
Siſs has told me, her Mrs. made no queſtion
But that ſhe would procure her ſelf a Huſband,
And her Brother a wife, in two days ſpace;
And had her other Brother been in Town,
'Twould have gone hard but ſhe'd a fitted him
With a wife alſo.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: She has done pritty well,
Having made ſure for her ſelf of my Brother,
Has put hers alſo in ſo fair a way
To th'Lady Lovewealth, it is ten to one
But he will carry her: but here he is,
And by his chearful looks I hope all's well.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: The night being far ſpent, and knowing, Madam,
There was ſuch work in hand as would detain you
From your accuſtom'd reſt, we have made bold,
This fair Lady and I, to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Madam, I had no ſooner given this Gentleman
A power over me, but he has made uſe of it
In commanding me hither.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: By your advice.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I am o'rejoy'd, Sir, to ſee your ſucceſs,
And wiſh your Ladyſhip all happyneſs
In this your choice.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: As I do you in yours.

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Ladyſhip, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay, for my part, I'm fully perſwaded
That all the Stars are in a cloſe conjunction
This very night: but, Madam, where's the reſt?
My Siſter, Madam—

sp.speaker: Dian.
sp.l: Gone about ſome new plot.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Madam, here comes your Brother and his Mate.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Brother, ſpeak, haſt thou ſped?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll anſwer for him.
Madam, he may thank your politick head
For having me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And my well acting in it.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I hope by this I've made an other match
Since I went hence.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: As how? pray let us hear.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Mr. Crosby being highly incenſed
Againſt you, Sir, whom he knew was his Rival,
Was pleas'd this night to ſend a Challenge to you.
I in your abſence, by the help of the dark,
Receiv'd that Meſſage, which he thought he had given
To your own ſelf. I was but juſt return'd
From the Rendezvous, where finding the miſtake
His Second had made, with ſome fair words,
And a promiſe of Marriage, I've brought him home.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: How! a promiſe of Marriage, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Yes, yes, which by this time I have made good
I hope, and yet no prejudice to you,
As you ſhall hear. The abuſed Lady Phanny
Through his wildneſs, as you know I had above,
And a Parſon in readineſs in the dark,
Under pretence of not being diſcovered,
He gave conſent it ſhould be without light:
There having brought Mr. Crosby, juſt now
l've ſlipt my hand from his, and in exchange
Have given him the Lady Phanny's hand:
I left them in this poſture, the Miniſter
Doing his office readily without book.
So giving them the ſlip, I am come hither.
By this, I hope th'are faſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: I wiſh it ſo.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why here is plot enough to make a Play!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Oh! here they come, and by their countenance
I hope all's well.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: Where's my Trappanner, ho!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I hope, Sir, you have pardon'd my deceit.

sp.speaker: Crosby.
sp.l: I thank your goodneſs for it, and do confeſs
You are that happy Star has guided me
To this ſhun'd haven which will prove my Bliſs,
Since I have paid that debt which through my Vows
I had contracted here. Your pardon, Sir,
For thoſe thoughts I once harbour'd againſt you
My Rival then, but now I hope my friend,
What ſay you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: That here you may command
Your Lady too.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: How now? who have we here?
My Brother ſure, or I am in a dream?

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Our Brother, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.l: 'Tis impoſſible, ſure.

sp.speaker: Y. Airy.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis even ſo: I am a married man,
And this my Lady, Brother.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Thank your fortune!

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: Siſter, and ſo may you, that he is yours.
For your ſake, Sir, I'll forget her late folly,
And thank the Heavens for deſigning her yours
At the ſame time ſhe ſought her own deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Y. Airy.
sp.l: You are all goodneſs, Sir, to pardon thus
My late preſumption.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: All ſhall be now forgot:
This is a night of Jubilee; from hence
We muſt baniſh all ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Pray let me come,
I'm Mrs. of the houſe, am I not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Cog.
sp.l: And of me too.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: I thought ſo much at leaſt;
Therefore, dear Brother, I muſt bid you welcome,
And to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Y. Airy.
sp.l: Dear Siſter, humble thanks.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: Madam, for your ſake, I'll praiſe him the more.

sp.speaker: Sir Am.
sp.l: My very good friends all, I am come here
To make my recantation, own my fault,
And willingly ſet a fine on my head
For my late folly: I therefore in preſence
Of all are here, declare this Gentleman, my Nephew,
Sole Heir to my Eſtate, after my death:
During my life, allow him every year
One thouſand pound. To this pray witneſs all,
Till I have made it good in lawful form
Under my Hand and Seal.

sp.speaker: Sir Cog. and Phill.
sp.l: We thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nob.
sp.l: All theſe joynings of hands, and no dance to't?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: Come, come, I'm for a dance, in which you'll ſee,
Though diſtinct Couples, we can all agree.

div.stage: After which, Enter Slye haling of Champagne.

sp.speaker: Slye.
sp.l: O! have I caught you, Sir? Now ſirrah, either fight
With me preſently, or prepare to die.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Ha! ha! ha! Begar me tink de fellow is made;
Vat pox do you no ſee dat de la Commedy is finiſh? look de
Your part, you will finde no ſuſh ting: go, go, and let de mee
To de la Compagnie.

div.stage: Champ. addreſſes to the Audience, the Epilogue.
div.p:
Gentliman, do in de la Comedye mee moſt no fitt, but me moſt ſwear, mee naturellement love de fit: et Jerny mee voul no ſwear;
derefor par conſequent mee come to tell de you, dat mee be de Poet Champion. If dere be man, homan, or little ſhild dat vill no clape de hand, and ſwear Jerny de Comedye is very good, begar, mee ſwear is no de underſtand de vit, nor de raiſon, et mee preſentement turne de la Comedye in de la Tragedy. Alon Jerny—
div.stage: Draws and flouriſhes during the Clap.
After the Clap, goes on thus.
div.p: So, very good; now becauſe you be all de civility, mee promiſs ſur mon honneur, mee voul no kill de you, and mee give de you de permiſſion to come here to morrow agin (for your argent Jerny) et ſo Meſieurs adieu; mee go tell de Poet de your courtoiſie.
